title-group.article-title: A new genus and new species of eriophyid mites from Papua New Guinea: a potential biological control agent ofFalcataria moluccana (Fabaceae)

sec.title: N/A
sec.p:
A new genus and new species of eriophyid mites from Papua New Guinea : a potential biological control agent of
Falcataria moluccana
( Fabaceae )

Biljana Vidoviƒá K a
,
Tatjana Cvrkoviƒá K b
,
Warea Orapa K c a
University of Belgrade , Faculty of Agriculture, Department of Entomology and Agricultural Zoology,
Nemanjina 6, 11080 Belgrade-Zemun, Serbia .

b
Institute for Plant Protection and Environment, Banatska 33, 11080 Belgrade , Serbia .

c
National Agriculture Research Institute, Sir Alkan Tololo Research Centre, PO Box 4415, Lae, Morobe
Province, Papua New Guinea .
Original research

sec.title: ABSTRACT
sec.p:
A new genus and species of the subfamily Nothopodinae , Colopodacini from Papua New Guinea are described and illustrated.
Solenidiversum falcatariae
gen. nov. sp. nov
.

infests
Falcataria moluccana (Miq.) Barneby & Grimes
( Fabaceae ) and causes erineum on both the leaf surfaces.
Solenodiversum
gen. nov.
has the solenidion on the inner side of tarsus I, tibiae of both legs completely fused with tarsus, all leg and ventral opisthosomal setae present, empodium entire and scapular tubercles on rear shield margin. With this new genus and species, the current number of Colopodacini is 16 genera and 41 species.
A key to the genera of the Colopodacini tribe is given.

sec.p:

Eriophyidae

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
of described species are monophagous, registered on only one host plant (
).

(Lindquist et al. 1996Õæ
).

Batai wood,
Falcataria moluccana (Miq.) Barneby & Grimes
( Fabaceae ) is a large, fast-

In the pursuit of a potential biological control agent for batai wood, eriophyid leaf gall mites have been identified and selected for further examination due to their potentially significant destructive capabilities. To date, a total of 47 eriophyid mite species have been described on host plants belonging to genera within the mimosoid clade (subfamily Caesalpinioidea DC. ). The species described are from the genera
Abacarus Keifer
,
Aceria Keifer
,
Aculops Keifer
,
Aculus Keifer
,
Heterotergum Keifer
,
Paratetra ChannaBasawanna
,
Pentamerus Roivainen
,
Phyllocoptes Nalepa
,
Porcupinotus Mohanasundaram
,
Tegonotus Nalepa
,
Tetra Keifer
and only one species has been described from the genus of the subfamily Nothopodinae Õæ tribe Nothopidini ‚Äì
Cosella deleoni (Keifer)
on the host plant Pinthecollobium guadalupense (Pers.) Chapm. (Amrine & Stasna 1994Õæ
).

The current literature has no records of eriophyid mites on
Falcataria moluccana
(syn.
Albizia moluccana Miq.
).

In this paper, one new genus and one new species of the subfamily Nothopodinae , tribe Colopodacini , are described. The mites were associated with
Falcataria moluccana
, causing erineum on both surfaces of the leaf, and were collected in Papua New Guinea . A key to the genera of the tribe Colopodacini described to date is provided.

sec.title: Material and methods
sec.p: Collection and morphological measurements

Plant samples of
Falcataria moluccana
were collected at Fanamafai Village, along Fangaloa Crossing, Kavieng District of New Ireland Province in Papua New Guinea . ( 02¬∞52‚Ä≤19.21‚Ä≥S Õæ 151¬∞09‚Ä≤20.37‚Ä≥E ).

F medium (
). Structures relevant for taxonomic identification were examined using an Olympus BX53 research microscope with phase contrast and measured using the software package cellSens Entry 2 (CS-EN-V2) on the same microscope. Specimens were illustrated using a camera lucida on a Leica DMLS research microscope with phase contrast.

The morphology and nomenclature follow Lindquist (1996), the genus classification is based on
and the nomenclature of the internal female genitalia follows
. Measurements and illustrations were made according to
and
. All measurements are given in micrometers (Œºm) and, unless otherwise stated, signify the length of the structure.

Plant names are in accordance with
on-line database. The holotype and the paratype slides are deposited in the collections of the Acarology Laboratory, Department of Entomology and Agricultural Zoology, Faculty of Agriculture, University of Belgrade , Serbia .
Scanning electronic microscopy

Scanning electron micrographs (SEM) were taken according to
by the technique of reconstructing eriophyids from dry plant material. The mite specimens are first transferred to Keifer‚Äôs medium I in a cavity slide and heated to about 140 oC on an electric plate to bring the mites to their more or less original shape. The specimens are then transferred briefly, about 1 munite, into a KCl-glycerol solution. Excess solution is sucked off with philtre paper and the mites are then placed on the SEM holder. For specimen preparation before being placed on the SEM stage, mites were sputter-coated with gold for 100 s under 30 mA ion current. The mites were then studied in the vacuum chamber of a JEOL Scanning Electron Microscope (JEOL-JSM6390, Peabody, MA, USA ) at the Laboratory of Electron Microscopy, Faculty of Agriculture, University of Belgrade , Serbia
DNA extraction, PCR amplification and sequencing

For molecular analysis, mites were removed by direct examination under a stereomicroscope from leaves of
F. moluccana
collected in Papua New Guinea , preserved in 96% ethanol, and stored at 4 ¬∞C until DNA extraction, which was performed in Serbia .

mixed-citation.named-content: A new genus and new species of eriophyid mites from Papua New Guinea: a potential biological control agent ofFalcataria moluccana (Fabaceae)

tp:taxon-treatment.tp:mixed-nomenclature:
Genus
Solenidiversum
gen. nov. Vidoviƒá
Zoobank: 1D18B589-59F1-4E76-988C-167423810536

tp:treatment-sec.p:
Type species
‚Äî
Solenidiversum falcatariae
sp. nov.

Diagnosis ‚Äî The subfamily
Nothopodinae Keifer 1956
are distinguished from the other subfamilies of Eriophyidae by: the tibia of the legs is reduced or completely fused with the tarsus, tibia I without setae and tarsus without spatulate projections.

Within the subfamily Nothopodinae , it is possible to distinguish two tribes,
Nothopodini Keifer 1956
and
Colopodacini Mohanasundaram 1984
. The characteristics of
tribe Colopodacini
are the presence of coxal setae 1b , coxae of leg I usually weakly divided and tibia of leg I completely fused with the tarsus, except in the genus
Thaicesa Ko√ßak & Kemal
, which has very small tibiae. The characteristics of
Nothopodini
are the absence of coxal setae 1b , coxae and tibiae of leg I variable.

Solenidiversum
gen. nov.
belongs to Colopodacini with coxal setae I 1 ( b ) present, tibiae of legs I and II completely fused with tarsusÕæ empodium entireÕæ solenidion on tarsus I on inner side of tarsusÕæ solenidion on tarsus II in dorsal positionÕæ all leg setae presentÕæ scapular tubercles on rear shield marginÕæ setae sc projecting backwardÕæ prodorsal shield with small subtriangular frontal lobeÕæ body vermiformÕæ opisthosoma evenly round and with annuli subequal dorsoventrally, entirely microtuberculatedÕæ all ventral opisthosomal setae presentÕæ accessory setae ( h1 ) absent.

Remarks ‚Äî It should be noted that fifteen genera have been described from the tribe Colopodacini . From nine of those genera, the tibia of leg I is completely fused with the tarsus (
Colopodacus Keifer
,
Apontella Boczek & Nuzzaci
,
Paracolopodacus Kuang & Huang
,
Adenocolus Meyer & Ueckermann
,
Pseudocolopodacus Kuang
,
Dicolopodacus Huang
,
Kuangella Wei
,
Taicolopodacus Huang & Wang
, and
Juxtacolopodacus Flechtmann & De Queiroz
) and in the other six
Thaicesa
( Ko√ßak & Kemal 2008 ,
Calliparus Li, Setibia Duarte

& Navia, Aricolopodos Duarte & Navia,
Calareolata Han & Zhang
and
Reginesus Reis & Navia
) the tibia is reduced and very short, but not completely fused with the tarsus ( Keifer 1960 Õæ Boczek and Nuzzaci 1988 Õæ Kuang and Huang 1994 Õæ Boczek and Chandrapatya 1996 Õæ
Meyer and Ueckermann 1997 Õæ Kuang 1997 Õæ Huang 2001 Õæ Wei and Quin 2002 Õæ Ko√ßak and

Kemal 2008Õæ Huang and Wang 2009 Õæ Flechtmann and De Queiroz 2010 Õæ
Li et al. 2010
Õæ
Reis et al. 2012
Õæ
Duarte et al. 2017
Õæ Han and Zhang 2019 ).

Differential diagnosis ‚Äî The new genus is placed in Colopodacini , Nothopodinae , Eriophyidae, Eriophyoidea. There are sixteenth genera in Colopodacini . This new genus has the solenidion on the inner side of tarsus I, differentiating it from all other genera of the tribe.

The feature of displaced solenidia of leg I has so far been recorded in the genus
Juxtacolopodacus
(tribe Colopodacini ), where the solenidion is displaced laterally, and in the genus
Floracarus
( Nothopodini ) with a solenidion on the inner side of the tarsus (
Flechtmann et al. 2010
, Meyer & Ueckermann 1997 ).

This new genus, like
Thaicesa
,
Adenocolus , Caliparus and Setibia
, has scapular tubercles and setae on rear prodorsal shield margin. It differs from
Thaicesa
and
Adenocolus
in the presence of bv setae on both legs (absent on both legs in
Thaicesa
, absent on leg II in
Adenocolus
). It differs from Caliparus by the fused tibia and tarsus (distinct tibia and tarsus in Caliparus ). This new genus is most similar to Setibia , because only these two genera within the tribe Colopodacini have a worm-like body shape, unlike the other fourteen genera of this tribe. It differs from this genus, however, in the complete fusion of the tibia with the tarsus on both legs (in Setibia the tibia is reduced, but distinct) and in the absence of a prominent frontal lobe as in Setibia.

Etymology ‚Äî The genus name
Solenidiversum
is a combination of Soleni (from the Latin solenidion ‚Äì optically inactive chemosensory seta) and diversum (from the Latin diversus , meaning opposite). It refers to the opposite positions of the solenidion on the tarsus of leg I (ventral positions) in relation to the positions of the solenidion on the tarsus of leg II (dorsal positions). Gender: neutral

Solenidiversum falcatariae
sp. nov. Vidoviƒá
Zoobank: CC826E3B-ABBB-4C5F-B47F-363DF1699A7B (

)

sec.title: Description
sec.p: FEMALE (n=10). Body vermiform 187 (166‚Äì194), 41 (38‚Äì45) wide, whitish in color. Gnathosoma 15 (12‚Äì16) projecting slightly downwards, chelicerae 9 (8‚Äì9), dorsal pedipal genual setae d 3. Prodorsal shield 22 (17‚Äì22) including the small subtriangular frontal lobe,

21 (20‚Äì22) wide. Triangular with a rounded frontal lobe over the gnathosomaÕæ median and admedian lines completeÕæ I pair of submedian lines present on anterior half, incompleteÕæ II and III pair of submedian lines incomplete, extending from anterior margin and ending ahead of prodorsal shield tuberclesÕæ in the lower half of the shield there are numerous dashes between all lines of prodorsal shieldÕæ on both lateral margins, of the rear of shield, there are areas with more numerous and densely dashes. Tubercles sc on rear shield margin 12 (11‚Äì12) apart, scapular setae sc 24 (22‚Äì26). Leg I 24 (19‚Äì24)Õæ femur 10 (8-10), ventral basifemural setae bv 6 (4‚Äì6)Õæ genu 4 (3‚Äì4), antaxial genual setae l‚Ä≥ 15 (12‚Äì16)Õæ tibiotarsus 7 (5‚Äì8), paraxial fastigial tarsal setae ft‚Ä≤ 9 (8‚Äì 11), antaxial fastigial tarsal setae ft‚Ä≥ 17 (14‚Äì18)Õæ tarsal solenidion œâ 4 (3‚Äì4)Õæ
tarsal empodium 5 (4‚Äì6), 6-rayed. Leg II 20 (16‚Äì20)Õæ femur 9 (7‚Äì9), ventral basifemural setae

bv 5 (5‚Äì7)Õæ genu 3 (3‚Äì4), antaxial genual setae l‚Ä≥ 6 (5‚Äì7)Õæ tibiotarsus 6 (5‚Äì6), paraxial fastigial tarsal setae ft‚Ä≤ ‚Ä≤ 4, antaxial fastigial tarsal setae ft‚Ä≥ 16 (14‚Äì17)Õæ tarsal solenidion œâ 7 (6‚Äì8)Õæ tarsal empodium 4 (4‚Äì5), 6‚Äì7-rayed. Coxigenital region with 5‚Äì6 semiannuli betwen coxae and genitalia. Coxisternal plates granulatedÕæ sternal line 6Õæ proximal setae on coxisternum I 1 ( b )
4 (4‚Äì5), tubercles 1b 4 apartÕæ anterolateral setae on coxistenum II ( 1a ) 20 (18‚Äì23), tubercles

1a 6 (5‚Äì6) apart, proximal setae on coxisternum II ( 2a ) 29 (25‚Äì32), tubercles 2a 12 (11‚Äì13) apart. External genitalia 10 (8‚Äì10), 12 (12‚Äì14) wide, granulated proximally and with two transverse curved lines distally, setae 3a 5 (5‚Äì6), 9 (8‚Äì11) apart. Internal genitalia with anterior, transversal apodeme trapezoidal, longitudinal bridge relatively long, spermathecal tubes directed latero-posterad, spermathecae egg-shaped, globose. Opisthosoma with subequal annuli: 55 (53‚Äì66) dorsal and 58 (56‚Äì68) ventral annuli. Dorsal and ventral opisthosoma with oval, elongated microtubercles close to the rear margins of annuli. Setae c2 14 (13‚Äì16), 27 (27‚Äì33) apart, on annulus 8 (8‚Äì9)Õæ setae d 34 (30‚Äì38), 24 (21‚Äì26) apart, on annulus 20 (18‚Äì22)Õæ setae e 41 (36‚Äì41), 19 (16‚Äì20) apart, on annulus 36 (36‚Äì42)Õæ setae f 16 (14‚Äì17), 10 (10‚Äì12) apart, on annulus 53 (52‚Äì63)Õæ seta h2 76 (74‚Äì83), 7 (7‚Äì8) apartÕæ setae h1 absent.

MALE (n=2). Smaller than females and generally similar to them, 130‚Äì150, 35‚Äì40 wide. Gnathosoma 10‚Äì12 curved down, cheliceral stylets 6‚Äì7. Prodorsal shield 17‚Äì19, 19‚Äì21 wide. Prodorsal shield tubercles on the rear shield margin 12‚Äì13 apart, setae sc 12‚Äì14, projecting posteriorly. Shield design similar to female. Leg I 16‚Äì18Õæ femur 7, setae bv 4Õæ genu 3, setae

l‚Ä≥ 9Õæ tibiotarsus 5, setae ft‚Ä≤ 8, setae ft‚Ä≥ 13Õæ solenidion œâ 3Õæ empodium em 4, and 6-rayed. Leg II 16Õæ femur 7, setae bv 4Õæ genu 3, genual setae l‚Ä≥ 5Õæ tibiotarsus 4, setae ft‚Ä≤ 3‚Äì4, setae ft‚Ä≥ 13Õæ solenidion œâ 7Õæ empodium em 4. Coxigenital region with 5‚Äì6 semiannuli between coxae and genitalia. Coxisternal plates granulatedÕæ sternal line 3Õæ setae 1b 3‚Äì4, 1b tubercles 3‚Äì4 apartÕæ setae 1a 11‚Äì12, 1a tubercles 6 apartÕæ setae 2a 19‚Äì22, 2a tubercles 13‚Äì14 apart. External genitalia 13‚Äì14 wide, epiandrum typically ornamented with small granules, setae 3a 3‚Äì5, 3a tubercles 10‚Äì11 apart, setae eu absent. Opisthosoma with subequal annuli: 54‚Äì56 dorsal and 54‚Äì56 ventral annuliÕæ setae c2 12‚Äì13, 37 apart, on annulus 6‚Äì7Õæ setae d 21‚Äì22, 24‚Äì 25 apart,
on annulus 15Õæ setae e 24‚Äì26, 18 apart, on annulus 30‚Äì32Õæ setae f 11‚Äì12, 10 apart, on annulus 49‚Äì52Õæ setae h2 30‚Äì35, 6‚Äì7 apart, setae h1 absent.

NYMPH (n=3). Body vermiform, 123‚Äì132, 40‚Äì43 wide. Gnathosoma 9‚Äì12, chelicerae 7‚Äì8. Prodorsal shield 17‚Äì19, 23 wide, scapular tubercles 15‚Äì16 apart, setae sc 9‚Äì10. Leg I 12‚Äì13, femur 5‚Äì6, setae bv 3Õæ genu 2‚Äì3, setae l‚Ä≥ 6‚Äì8Õæ tibiotarsus 3‚Äì4, setae ft‚Ä≤ 3‚Äì4, setae ft‚Ä≥ 9‚Äì11Õæ solenidion œâ 2‚Äì3Õæ empodium em 3‚Äì4, and 5-rayed. Leg II 11‚Äì12Õæ femur 4‚Äì5, setae bv

2Õæ genu 2, genual setae l‚Ä≥ 4‚Äì6, tibiotarsus 3, setae ft‚Ä≤ 2‚Äì3, setae ft‚Ä≥ 10‚Äì11Õæ solenidion œâ 4‚Äì5Õæ empodium em 3‚Äì4. Coxigenital region with 5‚Äì6 complete annuli, setae 3a 2, tubercles 4‚Äì5 apart. Coxisternal plate granulatedÕæ setae 1b 2, 1b tubercles 5 apartÕæ setae 1a 4‚Äì5, 1a tubercles 5‚Äì6 apartÕæ setae 2a 8, 2a tubercles 13‚Äì14 apart. Opisthosoma with subequal annuli: 40‚Äì45 dorsal and 44‚Äì50 ventral annuliÕæ setae c2 4-5, 32‚Äì33 apart, on annulus 8Õæ setae d 11‚Äì13, 22 apart, on annulus 16‚Äì17Õæ setae e 7, 12‚Äì14 apart, on annulus 27‚Äì29Õæ setae f 10, 11‚Äì12 apart, on annulus 40‚Äì45Õæ setae h2 18‚Äì19, 6‚Äì7 apart, setae h1 absent.

sec.title: Type host plant
sec.p:
Falcataria moluccana (Miq.) Barneby & Grimes
( Fabaceae )

sec.title: Type locality
sec.p:
Papua New Guinea : Fanamafai Village, along Fangaloa Crossing, Kavieng District, New Ireland Province ( 02¬∞52‚Ä≤19.21‚Ä≥S Õæ 151¬∞09‚Ä≤20.37‚Ä≥E Õæ Alt.
267 m .
a.s.l.).
Type material . Female holotype (slides 946/5) and paratypes 37 females , 3 males Õæ 10 nymphsÕæ 10 February 2021 , collected by Warea Orapa.

Additional material . Papua New Guinea : Kafa Road, South of Pimaga Government Station, Lake Kutubu District, SHP. ( 06¬∞31‚Ä≤42.67‚Ä≥S Õæ 143¬∞32‚Ä≤08.88‚Ä≥E Õæ Alt.
933 m .
a.s.l) 31

January 2021, 25 slides, collected by Warea Orapa. Relation to the host . The infestation caused by this mite results in the formation of white erineum on both surfaces of the leaflets, later the erineum darkens ( Fig. 3 ).

sec.title: Etymology
sec.p:
The species name is based on the host plant‚Äôs generic name,
Falcataria
.

sec.title: COI sequence
sec.p:
The whole barcode region (658 bp) of mtCOI was generated from three specimens
Solenidiof versum falcatariae sp. nov .
As all nucleotide sequences were 100% identical, only one of them was submitted to the GenBank database under accession number OQ401030. The translation of the nucleotide sequences resulted in 219 amino acid positions. Base pair frequencies show that the region is AT-rich (A: 0.242, C: 0.140, G: 0.147, T: 0.471).

sec.title: Acknowledgements
sec.p:
The authors would like to thank Prof. R. Petanoviƒá, University of Belgrade , Serbia , for the critical review of the manuscript and for her assistance on the nomenclature of the names
Solenidiversum
. Special gratitude is due to Dragica Smiljaniƒá (University of Belgrade , Belgrade-Zemun, Serbia ) for her technical support and Dr. Quentin Paynter (Manaaki Whenua-Landcare Research New Zealand ) for his support of the field work in Papua New Guinea .

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This study was supported by: Ministry of Education, Science and Technological Development of the Republic of Serbia , contract No. 451-03-68/2022-14/200116, No. 451-03-68/2022- 14/200010Õæ New Zealand Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade (MFAT) through the Managing Invasive Species for Climate Change Adaptation in the Pacific (MISSCAP) programme and Manaaki Whenua ‚Äì Landcare Research (PRJ2839, Subcontract No. 1920-23-039 G).

sec.title: Conflict of interest
sec.p: The authors declare that there is no conflict of interest regarding the publication of this paper.
